From what doth lead thereto; be rul'd by me,
And this Condition thou ſhalt never ſee.

div.head: Canto V. Or the Joyful Canto.
The joys of Heaven, and Songs of the Righteous.

q.p: Awake and ſing ye that dwell in the duſt,

lg.l: This Joyful Canto doth declare
The happy ſtate, and great welſare,
Of thoſe that in Chriſt's joys ſhall ſhare.
What ſongs may fit that happy ſtate,
Though their injoyments then ſo great
Will be, as no pen can relate.
First ſongs the Father cheifly eyes,
The ſecond the Son magnifies,
And praiſes his great victories.
The third ſongs wholly to this tend,
The Holy Spirit to commend,
And then this Canto hath an end.
BUT on the contrary the Righteous men
Shall have great pleaſures and rejoycings, when
They go into eternal life; then they
Shall ſhout and ſing, and well they may thus ſay,
Oh, oh, oh, Hallelujah! oh this day!
Oh, oh, Hallelujah, Hallelujah! who may
Our happineſs conceive? oh happy ſtate
What heart can reach it? what tongue it relate?
Yea well they may as Harpers ſtrike their ſtring,
And with great triumph thus, and better ſing.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: HAllelujah, oh happy day,
That ever we were born!
Oh well are we that we do ſee
This everlaſting morn!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Oh what are we
That we ſhould be
Thus lifted up on high?
We did not merit
Thus to inherit
Honour and dignity.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Bleſt be the Lamb
That here we came
Rais'd up from Death again.
'Tis by his blood
We have this good
Ever with him to reign.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Bleſſed for all that did befall
Be God for evermore:
Oh bleſſed be, that one in three,
Whom ever we adore!

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Who can ſet forth
His wond'rous worth?
It doth all things ſurpaſs.
It doth exceed
All that we read
And all that ever was.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Oh happy we who do him ſee,
Who all perfection is.
No Potentate, no Monarch great
Ever had joy like this.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Rivers of pleaſures
Beyond all meaſures,
Unto our lot doth fall.
No mixture is
In this our bliſs,
But it is bleſſing all.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: All things we have
That heart can crave,
And more then heart can reach:
None ever could
This joy unfold,
None ever could it preach.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Our joy ſurmounts
On all accounts,
All that we could believe:
All praiſe is due
To God moſt true;
He did us not deceive.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Oh glorious ſight!
Oh great delight!
None ever did behold
So rare a ſight,
A light ſo bright;
Our glory can't be told.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: All's infinite,
All is delight;
We have no ſorrow here.
Nothing of dark
No fading ſpark
All is moſt bright and clear.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: All, All is love,
All things above,
And all that is below:
We ſee no evil,
We fear no Devil;
Nothing but good we know.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Nothing but joy,
Nought to annoy,
Here we are void of fear.
For we are ſure
We ſhall endure
For ever happy here.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: Oh Majeſty!
Oh glory high!
What one is like to thee?
We 've our deſire,
Thee we admire.
To all eternity.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: Our bleſſedneſs
None can expreſs;
It is an ocean great:
All that excels
For ever dwells
In this moſt glorious ſeat.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: Bleſt be the Lord?
Bleſt be his Word.
Bleſt be his holy Spirit.
How happy we
In this One-Three
Our portion to inherit.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: Oh mighty King
Everlaſting
Beginning thou had'ſt none.
When nothing were,
Then thou waſt there;
Thou waſt thy ſelf alone.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: In thy ſelf bleſt
Thou had'ſt thy reſt,
Of us thou had'ſt no need.
Thou did'ſt poſſeſs
Full happineſs,
Thou'rt happineſs indeed.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Of thy good will
It to fulfil,
The Worlds foundation ſure
By thee was lay'd,
Thou it up-ſtay'd
At thy will to endure.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: The Word thou ſaid'ſt
All things thou mad'ſt.
Oh bleſſed be that Word,
Which did Being
To every thing
In thy good time afford.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: Bleſt be that love
That did thee move
Before the World was made;
To be the ſeat
Of thy works great
Or its foundations laid.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: To think of this
Eternal bliſs
And it prepare for us.
Oh what were we
That then by thee
We ſhould be car'd for thus.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: Bleſt be that thought
That us out ſought
And our great happineſs;
We do admire
The great deſire
Thou had'ſt us thus to bleſs.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: Could we be dear
Who nothing were
Unto thy Majeſty?
Thou did'ſt poſſeſs
That word expreſs
Which was with thee on high.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: All things were made
By him, and lay'd
On their foundation faſt.
That they might ſtand
At thy command
And at thy will might laſt.

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: 'Twas for his ſake
That thou did'ſt make
Inviſible Beings;
The Angels, Thrones,
Dominions,
And all viſible things.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: That him thou might,
And his great height,
Moſt gloriouſly diſplay:
And his fulneſs
Thereby expreſs,
That others know it may.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: But cheifly man
When thou began
Thou gratiouſly did'ſt view:
From him all which
The Seas did rich,
And on the Earth that grew.

lg.head: XXIX.
lg.l: Yea the Heavens bright,
With all their light,
And all the hoſts therein;
Thine hand did frame,
And gave the ſame
To ſerve and honour him.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: Whom thou in thine
Image divine
Did'ſt good and upright make:
And from his ſide
Did'ſt frame a Bride,
Whom he to him did take.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: A comely pair,
And very fair,
For though they naked were,
They found no ſhame
While void of blame,
Nor had they any fear.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: A Sabboath day,
For reſt had they
The ſeventh, when thou didſt reſt
From thy works all,
Both great and ſmall,
And therefore thou it bleſt.

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: A day wherein
They without ſin
Might with thy Majeſty
Have ſweet converſe,
Thy praiſe rehearſe,
And view thy great glory.

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: A Garden ſweet,
With pleaſures meet,
Thou put'ſt them in alſo,
Wherewith delight
Thy will they might
Learn of thee and it do.

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: Of life a Tree
Was given by thee,
That they might live for ay.
A River large
Which did diſcharge
Its ſtreams forth every way.

lg.head: XXXVI.
lg.l: All things that might
Give them delight
Thou on them didſt beſtow.
One only Tree
Withheld by thee
Was, good and ill to know.

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: Thou gav'ſt them food
Was only good;
Not good and evil both.
If both they would
Know, thou them told
Thou would'ſt with them be wroth.

lg.head: XXXVIII.
lg.l: Thou death didſt threat,
If they would eat,
That ſo thou might'ſt them ſcar:
That free from ill
They might live ſtill,
And from death keep them far.

lg.head: XXXIX.
lg.l: Yet them to try
Thou prov'dſt them by
A Serpent ſubtly wiſe:
Who thee did fault
Them to aſſault,
And cheated them with lies.

lg.head: XL.
lg.l: The Woman firſt
The bonds did burſt
Wherewith thou did'ſt them tye
Unto thee faſt.
The Man did taſte
By her means; both did dye.

lg.head: XLI.
lg.l: How happy a ſtate
Did'ſt thou create
And ſet them in, while they
Were innocent,
Without intent
Thy laws to diſobey?

lg.head: XLII.
lg.l: Man then was Lord
Of what thy word
Created for his ſake:
Of all things he
Had leave from thee,
But one Tree, to partake.

lg.head: XLIII.
lg.l: Pleaſures he had
To make him glad,
Sabboath and River too:
A ſpotleſs Wife,
A Tree of Life,
What ſhould'ſt thou for him do?

lg.head: XLIV.
lg.l: How great his good!
How might he ſtood!
How was he bound to thee!
His glory much;
No creature's ſuch.
But oh more happy we!

lg.head: XLV.
lg.l: Our ſtate exceeds,
Beyond all needs,
There was a Serpent there:
They did aſpire
To be yet higher;
But here's no Tempter here.

lg.head: XLVI.
lg.l: We are not in
Danger of ſin
Nor need we to aſpire:
Here's injoyment
Of all content
We nothing more deſire.

lg.head: XLVII.
lg.l: Tempted we were
But before here
We came to be thus bliſt:
Our tryal's paſt,
Sathan's down caſt,
And we his ſnares have miſt.

lg.head: XLVIII.
lg.l: Now we do reſt
For ever bleſt
From all temptations free:
Our danger's paſt,
Our joys ſhall laſt,
To all eternity

lg.head: XLIX.
lg.l: This is the day
That we did pray
And wreſtle to obtain:
From ſin ſet free
With thee to be
And never part again.

lg.head: L.
lg.l: Nothing we want
That thou did'ſt grant
To Adam heretofore:
Yea he far leſs
Then did poſſeſs
Then we now evermore.

lg.head: LI.
lg.l: We have a Reſt,
A day that's bleſt
A Sabboath day to be:
With thee we'r bleſt,
Thou art our Reſt,
And change we ne'r ſhall ſee.

lg.head: LII.
lg.l: Hallelujah,
Oh bleſſed day!
Who can thy glory ſpeak?
This Sabboath we
Perpetually
Keep, and it never break.

lg.head: LIII.
lg.l: Therein we ſing,
To thee our King;
Thy glory we behold.
Our work is this
Thy Name to bliſs,
Thy praiſes to unfold.

lg.head: LIV.
lg.l: A Paradiſe
Wherein there lies
All pleaſures ſweet and great:
With liberty
Perpetually
Thereof to take and eat.

lg.head: LV.
lg.l: An Heavenly Tree
Of life have we
Which doth us ever feed;
It doth us give
Ever to live
And nothing can we need.

lg.head: LVI.
lg.l: A River pure
Of Waters ſure,
Doth clear as Chryſtal run,
We with it meet
In every Street:
Our City needs no Sun.

lg.head: LVII.
lg.l: God is our light,
He ſhines moſt bright,
No Cloud doth him obſcure:
All things we ſee
Juſt as they be,
Our knowledge is moſt ſure.

lg.head: LVIII.
lg.l: Its always full,
Its never dull;
Our comforts ever flow.
Our Suns bright beams,
Our Rivers ſtreams,
No damp, no ebb, do know.

lg.head: LIX.
lg.l: All manner fruits
Which with us ſuits,
And may give us delight;
Our Tree doth bear
Throughout the year,
Moſt pleaſant to our ſight.

lg.head: LX.
lg.l: All is moſt ſweet
With which we meet;
Here's nothing ſharp or ſowre.
Pleaſures we have,
We can't more crave;
They're conſtant every hour.

lg.head: LXI.
lg.l: We need no Wives
To make our lives
More comfort us afford:
We never dye
Nor company
Need we at bed or board.

lg.head: LXII.
lg.l: No different ſex
Nothing to vex,
Nothing to tempt we know.
All perfect is,
All's full of bliſs,
Our tides are never low.

lg.head: LXIII.
lg.l: We do all reign
And Lords remain
Over all creatures:
We never ſhall
From our heigths fall,
Our Kingdom ever dures.

lg.head: LXIV.
lg.l: We have no night
Nor borrowed light,
No Moon or Candle here:
For it alway
Is perfect day
The Sun is not ſo clear.

lg.head: LXV.
lg.l: Oh bleſſed King
From whom doth ſpring
This ſtate of happineſs;
We'll ſing thy praiſe
All our All-days
Thy goodneſs we'll confeſs.

lg.head: LXVI.
lg.l: When Adam fell
What tongue could tell
What was our miſery?
In him we were,
He did us bear,
And in him we did dye.

lg.head: LXVII.
lg.l: Branches were we
Of him the Tree,
The root wherefrom we grew
A flood of woe
Did us ore flow
When his fall made us rue.

lg.head: LXVIII.
lg.l: Our root did rot
Having forgot
The hand that did it plant,
The branches muſt
Then turn to duſt
For they their life did want.

lg.head: LXIX.
lg.l: In him we fell
As low as Hell;
Death upon us did ſeiſe.
Woes in us bred,
Away quite fled
All comfort, joy and eaſe.

lg.head: LXX.
lg.l: Great was our fault
At one aſſault,
And when ingaged thus;
God to reject
And in effect
To thruſt away from us.

lg.head: LXXI.
lg.l: Great miſery
Therefore did lye
Upon us by deſert;
Of good bereft
To be quite left
To utmoſt grief and ſmart.

lg.head: LXXII.
lg.l: We were beguil'd,
Sin us defil'd
And had ſo filthy made,
That God and we
Could not agree:
Of him we were afraid.

lg.head: LXXIII.
lg.l: Mortallity
Did by and by
Seiſe on us; oh what pain
Did we procure
For to endure
Till duſt we turn'd again!

lg.head: LXXIV.
lg.l: Yea God we loſt
Which was the moſt
Sad loſs could us befall:
His wrath alſo
We fell into,
And into deadly thrall.

lg.head: LXXV.
lg.l: We loſt that light
Which gave us ſight
And ceaſt to underſtand:
And led by luſt
Became unjuſt
Subject to ſins command.

lg.head: LXXVI.
lg.l: The old Serpent
A falſe light lent
Which made us judge amiſs,
And in vain things
To ſeek the ſprings
Of everlaſting bliſs.

lg.head: LXXVII.
lg.l: By thoſe inſlav'd
We miſbehav'd
Our ſelves in every thing;
We acted evil,
We ſerv'd the Devil,
Took him for guide and King.

lg.head: LXXVIII.
lg.l: Luſt was vice-King
That was the ſpring
Of actions light and grave,
Our ſubtlety
That was the ſpy
Which us falſe counſel gave.

lg.head: LXXIX.
lg.l: Theſe did conſpire
To make us higher,
In our falſe fond conceit:
For Heaven the ſhow'd
Falſe pleaſures ſtrow'd
And therewith did us cheat.

lg.head: LXXX.
lg.l: Oh woful plight!
Oh ruful ſight!
This was our fallen caſe:
In thraldom dwelt
Seldom it felt
But took it for ſolace.

lg.head: LXXXI.
lg.l: In darkneſs deep,
In dangers ſteep,
Perplexities and fears:
In depths of Hell
Then did we dwell
And ſpend our woful years.

lg.head: LXXXII.
lg.l: God was but juſt
Us out to thruſt
From him, we left him firſt:
And then a Hell
Of woe befell
Becauſe of him accurſt.

lg.head: LXXXIII.
lg.l: In which ſad ſtate
Objects of hate
And enemies to God,
Without his ſight
And deſtroy'd quite,
We ever had abode.

lg.head: LXXXIV.
lg.l: But that the Lord
Though he abhor'd
Then fellowſhip with us,
Yet pittiful,
In love did pull
Us out, and help us thus.

lg.head: LXXXV.
lg.l: The mighty Word
Of this great Lord
By whom he did us make;
Tha Wiſdom high
Our ſins did ſpy,
But not with them partake.

lg.head: LXXXVI.
lg.l: A fountain pure
He did endure,
In whom God took delight;
He was beloved
And well approved,
For he did always right.

lg.head: LXXXVII.
lg.l: Angels ſome fell
And down to Hell
Were thruſt 'cauſe they rebel'd:
God paſt them by
And let them lye
In chains of darkneſs held.

lg.head: LXXXVIII.
lg.l: But he by whom
All good doth come,
Moſt holy did abide.
By him God now
His love did ſhow
And mercy glorifi'd.

lg.head: LXXXIX.
lg.l: Him he decreed
In this our need,
That ſaved we might be,
To be ſent forth
This one of worth
Able to ſet us free.

lg.head: XC.
lg.l: The Womans ſeed,
Of David's breed
To be: He was ordained
A man of grief
To bring relief
That we might be regain'd.

lg.head: XCI.
lg.l: Oh loving Lord!
Oh mighty word!
The ſource of all our bliſs!
To be ador'd
With one accord
For evermore in this.

lg.head: XCII.
lg.l: This grand deviſe,
Ground of our riſe,
Let men and Angels praiſe:
Angels admir'd
And much deſir'd
This to behold always.

lg.head: XCIII.
lg.l: This we admire
This with deſire
Now fully ſatisfi'd
We look upon,
We make our ſong;
Its praiſe we cannot hide.

lg.head: XCIV.
lg.l: Here fully we
Behold and ſee
Gods admirable love;
And perfectly
We here deſcry,
All his perfections move.

lg.head: XCV.
lg.l: In this we live,
This all doth give,
Which we injoy and have.
Can we forget
To ſet forth it
Which did us help and ſave?

lg.head: XCVI.
lg.l: This God fore-teld;
This all forth-held
Both Law and Prophets too.
This all upheld,
This we beheld
To raiſe us up from woe.

lg.head: XCVII.
lg.l: This with a blow
Did overthrow
The Devils Kingdom quite;
This did deſtroy
What did annoy,
What kept us from the light.

lg.head: XCVIII.
lg.l: This to declare
Let us not ſpare;
This is the myſtery
We now behold
And can unfold
With all its treaſury.

lg.head: XCIX.
lg.l: With eye to this
The God of bliſs
Ere ſince our dreadful fall,
Before it was
Yet brought to paſs
In act, did order all.

lg.head: C.
lg.l: What mercies we
Receiv'd, we ſee
Proceeded all here-fro:
We that have bliſs
They who did miſs
Beholden were hereto.

lg.head: CI.
lg.l: Though juſtice them
Who did contemn
And ſlight it doth deſtroy;
To us that live
Mercy doth give
And Juſtice too all joy.

lg.head: CII.
lg.l: Mercy did all
Reſpect ith' fall
And help for them provide;
They who refus'd
And it abus'd
His juſtice muſt abide.

lg.head: CIII.
lg.l: Thoſe things that we
Could not ſo ſee,
While mortal fleſh we had,
(For then our ſight
Was not ſo bright
Though we ſaw what did glad).

lg.head: CIV.
lg.l: Theſe things we now
Do clearly know
Their reaſon now we ſee.
Our vails are gone,
Darkneſſes none
Within our hearts now be.

lg.head: CV.
lg.l: We ſee it's true
In time moſt due,
God ſent his only Son
Of woman made,
As he had ſaid,
As ne'r before was done.

lg.head: CVI.
lg.l: Angels it ſee
And did agree
With joy it to declare:
Angels and we
Agreed now be,
And knit together are.

lg.head: CVII.
lg.l: Though in our fleſh
Us to refreſh,
It was that Chriſt appear'd:
For us to dye
Our death thereby
To vanquiſh which we fear'd.

lg.head: CVIII.
lg.l: Angels had not
Our fleſh, or ſpot
Of ſin therein, as we:
Yet they who ſtood
I'th truth were good
And joy'd our good to ſee.

lg.head: CIX.
lg.l: Under the Law
The Word us ſaw;
Under the Law came he;
That he that way
Our debts might pay
And by Death ſet us free.

lg.head: CX.
lg.l: Our bands to break
He did them take
And with them he was bound:
God's cords we burſt,
Chriſt was accurſt,
That he might heal our wounds.

lg.head: CXI.
lg.l: We were condemn'd
Who had contemn'd
God's holy Word and will:
He was contemn'd,
Miſus'd, condemn'd,
Our evils did him kill.

lg.head: CXII.
lg.l: For us he dyed,
Being crucified
Suſtain'd a cruel death:
Was broke with grief
Us'd as a thief,
Till he gave up his breath.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: His grave was made
And body laid
With the rich and unjuſt:
His honour high
Deſpis'd did lye,
All cover'd up with duſt.

lg.head: CXIV.
lg.l: Oh wondrous ſight!
Oh love moſt bright!
Never the like was ſeen.
That one ſo high
So low ſhould lye
Poor caytiffs to redeem.

lg.head: CXV.
lg.l: Of men what one
For men undone
His Son would ſo abaſe?
For enemies
That him deſpiſe
That they might be in place!

lg.head: CXVI.
lg.l: Yet ſuch a love
The Lord above
To us when poor did ſhow:
For bankrupt us
He made him thus
To pay what we did owe.

lg.head: CXVII.
lg.l: His wiſdom here
Did ſtrange appear
The World was pos'd hereby:
Its eye was blind
And could not find
Hereof the myſtery.

lg.head: CXVIII.
lg.l: This it befool'd,
This it quite gull'd,
This croſs ſo croſs did lye;
They ſtumbled here,
And could not bear
That 'twas God's Son did dye.

lg.head: CXIX.
lg.l: It did deride
And crucifi'd
This myſtery again;
As if that he
God could not be
That ſuch things did ſuſtain.

lg.head: CXX.
lg.l: This wiſdoms height
Did dim the ſight
O'th' Serpents eye ſo ſore,
He could not ſee
Thoſe heights here be
Yet did againſt them roar.

lg.head: CXXI.
lg.l: This brake his head,
This down did tread
His craft and power, who
Had man brought down
And quite ore-thrown
Into a pit of wo.

lg.head: CXXII.
lg.l: Here wiſdom we
And power did ſee
When God did clear our eyes;
The law fulfil'd
Its curſe was quel'd
Whon Chriſt from grave did riſe.

lg.head: CXXIII.
lg.l: For here it was
That God did paſs
Sentence upon our ſin:
He judg'd it here.
Chriſt did it bear
For us who fell therein.

lg.head: CXXIV.
lg.l: This vanquiſht Death,
Appeaſed wrath,
Did juſtice ſatifie:
Pardon for more
Then Adam's ſcore
Was purchaſed hereby.

lg.head: CXXV.
lg.l: Great pleaſure here
(As did appear)
God took, who the third day
Without delays
Did him up raiſe
From the grave where he lay.

lg.head: CXXVI.
lg.l: And did him take
Even for the ſake
Of what he ſuffered
To be on high
In his body,
And of all power the Head.

lg.head: CXXVII.
lg.l: Here God did lay
A certain ſtay
And ſure foundation
Of all his acts
And mighty facts
For man's ſalvation.

lg.head: CXXVIII.
lg.l: Of all our hope
The under-prop,
While we had not attain'd:
Of all the bleſs
We do poſſeſs
Now we the end have gain'd.

lg.head: CXXIX.
lg.l: Here lay the ground,
Here God did found
Our ſlidden hearts and feet,
Hence all the flood
Of all the good
Wherewith we ere did meet.

lg.head: CXXX.
lg.l: Yea on this ground
God did new found
The Earth and World again:
Both as it was
Till it did paſs,
And as it doth remain.

lg.head: CXXXI.
lg.l: Here he fulfil'd
What was forth-held
Of a prepared Feaſt.
All ready here
That might us chear
So as no want i'th' leaſt.

lg.head: CXXXII.
lg.l: The holy Spirit
As he did merit
Fully God did him give.
That for his praiſe
He might us raiſe
From Death, and make us live.

lg.head: CXXXIII.
lg.l: From darkneſs great
Wherein we ſate
From Death to Life, from Thrall
To Liberty,
Of his mercy
Thereby he did us call.

lg.head: CXXXIV.
lg.l: He ſent forth light,
He gave us ſight,
And turn'd our hearts to mind
What he held forth,
That ſo its worth
And goodneſs we might find.

lg.head: CXXXV.
lg.l: He gave his ſpeech
And did beſeech
Us to conſider well:
He gave an ear
That we might hear
The things that he did tell.

lg.head: CXXXVI.
lg.l: Full oft when we
His light did ſee
We winked with our eyes:
It did diſpleaſe us
It did diſ-eaſe us
Faulting our vanities.

lg.head: CXXXVII.
lg.l: Ofttimes we heard
But then we fear'd
Leaſt what we heard ſhould mar
Our falſe pretences,
Wrong confidences,
And put it from us far.

lg.head: CXXXVIII.
lg.l: Ofttimes we felt
The power that dwelt
In him and in his truth:
Almoſt we turn'd
And yet oft ſpurn'd;
Thus dealt we from our youth.

lg.head: CXXXIX.
lg.l: Oh how we lov'd
What he reprov'd!
How loath with it to part!
From idols vain
How loath t'abſtain
Although they caus'd us ſmart.

lg.head: CXL.
lg.l: But oh his love!
That did him move
To paſs by our miſdeeds.
He did forgive,
And made us live,
His gratiouſneſs exceeds.

lg.head: CXLI.
lg.l: In miſery
That we ſhould dye
He had no will at all.
He interceded
And for us pleaded;
And yet again did call.

lg.head: CXLII.
lg.l: His patient
Good deportment,
His lamb-like gentleneſs,
His ſuffering long
Our many a wrong,
Oh what tongue can expreſs!

lg.head: CXLIII.
lg.l: How oft his love
Did our hearts move
And make us to him look?
How oft did we
Look back to ſee
The Idols we forſook?

lg.head: CXLIV.
lg.l: It was the ſtrength
The power and length
Of his dear love unto us,
His words of grace
His pleaſant face
His conſtancy to wooe us.

lg.head: CXLV.
lg.l: His excellence,
His love immenſe,
The freeneſs of his grace
Which caught our heart
And made us part
With all him to embrace.

lg.head: CXLVI.
lg.l: Oh had he not
Ofttimes forgot
Our great unkindneſſes:
And look't away
From what each day
We acted quite amiſs.

lg.head: CXLVII.
lg.l: If with his eyes
Iniquities
Againſt us he had markt,
How we rebel'd
Our luſts faſt held,
The light he gave us darkt.

lg.head: CXLVIII.
lg.l: We had been then
Like yonder men
Who caſt out of his fight,
Do yell and cry
Moſt hideouſly
Throughout their endleſs night.

lg.head: CXLIX.
lg.l: But there is none
Save him alone,
None like him conſtant is;
His conſtancy
Was our ſafety
And brought us to this bliſs.

lg.head: CL.
lg.l: Can it be told
How manifold
Our ſtubborneſſes were?
Our great neglects,
And diſreſpects
Committed year by year?

lg.head: CLI.
lg.l: How much to do
He had to wooe
Before he did obtain?
How oft in heart
We did depart,
When wooed, from him again?

lg.head: CLII.
lg.l: What vanities
Did draw our eyes
From looking him upon?
How often we
Refus'd to ſee
His great ſalvation?

lg.head: CLIII.
lg.l: How dull we were
His voice to hear,
How oft we ſtopt our ears?
How we gave way
Day after day,
To luſts, or cares, or fears?

lg.head: CLIV.
lg.l: How oft, when he
Had cleans'd us, we
Did us again defile?
How oft confeſt
Yet not redreſt?
How much we hid through guile?

lg.head: CLV.
lg.l: A ſpring of ſin
We had within
Running continually;
No good in us,
How marvailous
Was his love and mercy?

lg.head: CLVI.
lg.l: To each good deed
That did proceed
From us through his good grace
Sin did adhere
And it beſmear
Such was our wretched caſe.

lg.head: CLVII.
lg.l: But oh his love
Did not remove!
But conſtantly abide;
Love made him blind
And not to mind
Our ſins but them oft hide.

lg.head: CLVIII.
lg.l: So as that God
Ofttimes his rod
Forbore on us to lay:
And paſſing by
Iniquity
He turn'd his wrath away.

lg.head: CLIX.
lg.l: A fountain great
He open ſet,
And there us purifi'd.
And if he chode
Yet love he ſhow'd
And did not always chide.

lg.head: CLX.
lg.l: Sometimes he hid
His face, and did
An angry count'nance ſhew.
That he might make
Us ſin forſake
And be to him more true.

lg.head: CLXI.
lg.l: Oft by ſome croſs
Some grief or loſs
He made us him to ſeek,
And then we felt
His love to melt
How gentle he and meek.

lg.head: CLXII.
lg.l: His loving mind
Unto mankind
Appearing did us ſave.
That did us make
Thoſe things forſake
Which did us fore-inſlave.

lg.head: CLXIII.
lg.l: Nor did he grieve
Us to receive
When unto him we came.
But readily
Did juſtifie
And waſh us in his Name.

lg.head: CLXIV.
lg.l: He by his power
Us every hour
Did keep in his great love.
Which every way
He did diſplay
As he did ſee't behove.

lg.head: CLXV.
lg.l: What he did by
Pleading on high
God's mercy to obtain;
And what from thence
He did diſpence
Made us with him remain.

lg.head: CLXVI.
lg.l: To him to cleave
Him never leave:
Or if we went aſtray,
Our good ſhepheard
Did us regard
And reduce to his way.

lg.head: CLXVII.
lg.l: His love us drew,
And made us true,
And hid us when we fail'd:
Him to forgo
Who lov'd us ſo
Nothing with us prevail'd.

lg.head: CLXVIII.
lg.l: To him we nought,
That good was, brought,
No good thing we could do:
He who us bought
All in us wrought
And helpt us againſt our foe.

lg.head: CLXIX.
lg.l: What we did want,
He did us grant,
We could but aſk and have;
Aſkig aright
And in his light,
Yea much unaſkt he gave.

lg.head: CLXX.
lg.l: He to us clave,
He did us ſave
Or elſe we had been gone;
He did begin
And never lin
Till all things he had done.

lg.head: CLXXI.
lg.l: He in his armes
Kept us from harmes
He did us ſafely bear:
He did us feed,
Keep, ſave, and lead,
Untill he brought us here.

lg.head: CLXXII.
lg.l: Something we wore
On Adam's ſcore
As we from him did ſpring:
So long as Death
Held us i'the' Earth
From whence he did us bring.

lg.head: CLXXIII.
lg.l: The Serpents ſeed
Which he did breed
Within us and without,
Did dog us too
Us to undo
And compaſt us about.

lg.head: CLXXIV.
lg.l: Through Chriſt our ſhield
We won the field,
He was our Captain brave:
Down fell our fleſh
We ſprung up freſh;
He brought us out from grave.

lg.head: CLXXV.
lg.l: Oh faithful friend
Unto the end
Who did us never fail?
Through him we ſtood
'Gainſt all the flood,
He made us to prevail.

lg.head: CLXXVI.
lg.l: Our Prophet he
Who made us ſee
The way of truth and right.
He ſent that guide
That did abide
With comfort, ſtrength, and light.

lg.head: CLXXVII.
lg.l: He did as Prieſt
Upon his Breaſt
Us in the Heavens preſent:
Our good procur'd,
Our weal aſſur'd;
Our evils did prevent.

lg.head: CLXXVIII.
lg.l: He was our King,
All good did bring:
Gave Laws, made us them choſe.
Rul'd with his arme,
Kept us from harme,
Subdued all our foes.

lg.head: CLXXIX.
lg.l: Yea all our wound
He up hath bound
As our Phiſitian good.
Our maladies
With remedies
He cured by his Blood.

lg.head: CLXXX.
lg.l: Yea Prophets he
Made us to be,
And Heavenly Prieſts and Kings:
To offer praiſe,
And raign always
Over all other things.

lg.head: CLXXXI.
lg.l: Oh happy we
This day that ſee
When nothing doth annoy!
We have no pain
Nor grief ſuſtain;
But we are fil'd with joy.

lg.head: CLXXXII.
lg.l: Oh bleſt be he
By whom this we
For ever do poſſeſs,
Let creatures all
Before him fall
And him for ever bleſs.

lg.head: CLXXXIII.
lg.l: But we much more
Will him adore
Who are his choice delight:
Whom he doth fill
Of great good will
With pleaſures in his ſight.

lg.head: CLXXXIV.
lg.l: Were every part
Of us a heart
Yet he ſhould have them all.
Were each a tongue
And his praiſe ſung
By each, 't would be too ſmall.

l.hi: To this our King
Who did us bring
To this All-Happineſs,
Let's ſing a ſong
Eternal-long
His praiſes to expreſs.
Hallelujah.

div.head: Another to Christ.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Oh holy glorious King
The Mighty Prince of Peace!
Thou art the Lamb, by whom we came
From ſin to have releaſe.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: To thee we owe our ſelves,
To thee all praiſe is due:
To thee O King, we'll praiſes ſing
A ſong of praiſes new.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Oh mighty Word of God,
Gods dear and only Son!
Thou did'ſt us know when we were low,
When we were quite undone.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Thou had'ſt no need of us,
For thou wert God above:
And we nothing to thee could bring,
And yet thou did'ſt us love.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Thou in the form of God
Waſt high and rich indeed:
Therefore of us who were but duſt
Thou could'ſt not ſtand in need.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Thou, thou, all glorious art,
The Father thee poſſeſt
When he began his works, even then
Thou laydeſt in his Breaſt.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Before his works of old
Were either fram'd or wrought,
The ancient hills, or fruitful fields,
Or Earth, thou waſt forth brought.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: The Father purpoſed
His purpoſes of old
In thee; who art, and do'ſt impart
His wiſdom manifold.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: When he the Heavens prepar'd,
And the foundations lay'd
Of the vaſt Earth, in joy, and mirth,
Thou ever by him ſtay'd.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Before the World was made,
The day, or darkſom night;
Fountain or deep, or Mountain ſteep,
Thou, thou waſt his delight.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: By thee the Worlds he made,
And all things more or leſs;
Without thee nought to paſs was brought,
Thou worthy art of bleſs.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: By thee he made us men,
And in thine Image clean;
All things we ſee, were made for thee,
And all the things unſeen.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Thou art the heir of all,
And in thee all things ſtand,
The Life that laſts, and Death out-caſts;
Thou all things do'ſt command.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: Thou art th' eternal truth,
The everlaſting light,
The unity; all without thee
Be falſhood, ſtrife, and night.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: The Angels thou did'ſt make,
Thoſe which did not abide,
Worthily fell down into Hell,
The recompence of pride.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: We by thee made, fell too
By liſtning to the lies
Which th' old Serpent, did firſt invent,
Aſpiring to be wiſe.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: Wiſdom we had in thee,
And wiſe thou did'ſt us make;
Wiſer to be fooliſhly, we
Preſum'd thee to forſake.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: While we thy holy Word
And thy command divine
Departed fro, and our ſelves to
The Serpent did incline.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Great was the miſery
Which we were plung'd into,
For from thee gone God we had none:
Our ſtate was full of woe.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: God gave us what was meet,
And that whereby we might
The Tempters wiles which did beguile us
Have all avoyded quite.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: Our fall was of our ſelves,
It did not come from thee:
We willingly the way to dye
Did chuſe; but thou wert free.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Yet bleſſed be that will
That did permit our fall:
And whatſoere permitted were
To any of us all.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: For now we ſee 'twas well
That God did ſo permit,
And not withhold that Serpent old
From tempting us to it.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: For hereby he hath ſhew'd
His attributes moſt clear:
How fooliſh we, how dear to thee
And unto him we were.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: That ſo we in our ſelves
No more might put our truſt,
Or liſten to what led us fro
Thee, to fulfil our luſt.

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: Yea thereby to himſelf
Our hearts he doth indear,
While we do ſee what for us he
Hath done, while ſuch we were.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: And ſo it hath ingag'd
Us wondrouſly to thee:
That thou ſo high vouchſafeſt to dye
To ſet ſuch caytiffs free.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: When we all helpleſs were,
And hopeleſs were become,
Thou did'ſt us ſave, our foes out drave,
Brought'ſt us to thy kingdom.

lg.head: XXIX.
lg.l: There's nothing in theſe acts
But big with love it is;
From firſt to laſt, we love do taſte,
And thee for ever bliſs.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: No ſhorter date can be
Sufficient to expreſs
Our hearty ſenſe of ſo immenſe
A love, and it confeſs.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: Yea wiſdom too we ſee
In ſuffring that our fall
It was, O King, glory to bring
To thee in our recal.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: That thou might'ſt be made known,
And the Father in thee;
That thy love might ſhine forth moſt bright,
And we more happy be.

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: We never can expreſs
Our thanks ſufficiently,
That thou O King did'ſt back us bring,
And to that end did'ſt dye.

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: Let's then ſtrike up our ſtrings,
As Harpers full of skill,
And ſing our ſong All our ay-long,
Till we do ſing our fill.

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: What one is like to thee,
Oh holy glorious one!
What did thee move us thus to love,
When we were all undone.

lg.head: CXXXVI.
lg.l: Thou in thy ſelf waſt bleſt,
Thou character expreſs
Of Gods perſon, his only Son,
His Glories full brightneſs.

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: It was exceeding love
And goodneſs to us when
I'th' duſt we lay, and were but clay
To make us living men.

lg.head: XXXVIII.
lg.l: In thy divine Image
And to be like to thee
A living ſoul, and to controule
All things in Earth and Sea.

lg.head: XXXIX.
lg.l: How could the duſt deſerve
To be preferred ſo?
It was only thy pleaſure high
Thus thereunto to do.

lg.head: XL.
lg.l: Yet as it did no good
Such favour to procure,
So it no bad within it had;
For all thy works were pure.

lg.head: XLI.
lg.l: Whereas we not only
Void of all goodneſs were;
But had done ill, yet 'twas thy will
Favour to us to bear.

lg.head: XLII.
lg.l: All thoſe expreſſions great
Of love, when we were duſt,
We valued not, but quite forgot
To ſatisfie a luſt.

lg.head: XLIII.
lg.l: The Serpent, who no good
Had done for us at all,
Far before thee preferred we
When we from thee did fall.

lg.head: XLIV.
lg.l: For without any ſhew
That it was true he ſaid
We took his lye, threw thy truth by;
Thy love aſide we laid.

lg.head: XLV.
lg.l: Oh great ingratitude!
Folly and madneſs great!
So eaſily to throw thee by,
And ſuffer ſuch a cheat.

lg.head: XLVI.
lg.l: Whereby we were defil'd
And made thine enemies:
Very unjuſt and fil'd with luſt
And all things good deſpiſe.

lg.head: XLVII.
lg.l: Yet that thou might'ſt us ſave
Thou waſt content to be
For us made fleſh, in our likeneſs,
Such ſin except, as we.

lg.head: XLVIII.
lg.l: Thou did'ſt not take the form
Of ſome great King or Lord:
Like a ſervant, poor and in want,
Thou we'rt of men abhor'd.

lg.head: XLIX.
lg.l: In which abaſed forme
Great grief thou did'ſt ſuſtain;
Yea for our good to ſhed thy blood
Thou dideſt not diſdain.

lg.head: L.
lg.l: Oh wond'rous love indeed
That one ſo great and high,
Who did proceed from God, ſhould bleed
And for us ſinners dye.

lg.head: LI.
lg.l: Beſides reproaches, blows,
Abuſes, ſhame and ſcorn,
Thy bloody ſweat, agony great,
Whereby thy life was worn.

lg.head: LII.
lg.l: The curſe which was our due
Thou alſo did'ſt endure:
In the grave lay, till the third day
Our freedom to procure.

lg.head: LIII.
lg.l: Yea alſo thou went'ſt down
Into the lower Hell
As one bereft of God, and left;
Thy griefs no tongue can tell.

lg.head: LIV.
lg.l: It was no gain from us
That thou could'ſt get thereby;
When we moſt had we could not add
Unto thy Majeſty.

lg.head: LV.
lg.l: But how much leſs when we
Had loſt what thou did'ſt give,
And nothing had, but what was bad
And were unfit to live!

lg.head: LVI.
lg.l: Oh what was ſinful man
That thou ſhould'ſt him ſo love?
At ſuch a coſt to ſave the loſt
What pitty did thee move?

lg.head: LVII.
lg.l: How can we but confeſs
That thine of right we are?
Since thou us made, thy life down laid,
Us when ſinners to ſpare?

lg.head: LVIII.
lg.l: And yet that was not all,
Thy love did ſo exceed;
'Twas not only leaſt we ſhould dye
That for us thou did'ſt bleed.

lg.head: LIX.
lg.l: Thou like to us was't made,
And our deſerts did'ſt bear,
That we might be made like to thee,
Thy robes of glory wear.

lg.head: LX.
lg.l: Oh depth! oh heigth of love!
None may compare with thee;
So low to lye, that we ſo high,
Who were ſo low, might be.

lg.head: LXI.
lg.l: Which thing to bring about
God raiſed thee again;
For pangs of death, or Hell beneath
Could not thee long detain.

lg.head: LXII.
lg.l: Becauſe thou art the life,
The life eternal, and
Againſt that life no mortal ſtrife
Of Death or Hell could ſtand.

lg.head: LXIII.
lg.l: The Serpent and his ſlaves,
Did ſtrive thee down to hold;
But all in vain, thou roſe again,
As was of thee foretold.

lg.head: LXIV.
lg.l: Oh mighty conqueror!
A glorious conqueſt here,
Thou o ••• evil, ſin, World and Devil,
Triumphantly did'ſt bear!

lg.head: LXV.
lg.l: This was the glorious fight,
This was the day indeed
Which God did make for his Names ſake,
This did from him proceed.

lg.head: LXVI.
lg.l: Theſe were the wars of God,
A battel bravely fought,
'Twixt th' innocent, and the Serpent,
Whereby our peace was wrought.

lg.head: LXVII.
lg.l: No war was like to this,
This the foundation laid
Of all the blows and overthrows
Upon the foes ſince made.

lg.head: LXVIII.
lg.l: Thoſe were the mortal foes
Of God and mankind too;
'Gainſt God's glory and Man's ſafety,
Their malice thy did ſhow.

lg.head: LXIX.
lg.l: Oh Prince of might elect,
God's dear and only Son,
Thou them withſtood unto thy blood,
Wherethrough the field was won.

lg.head: LXX.
lg.l: This field for us was fought;
Their helpleſs prey were we.
But thou them foil'd and their plot ſpoil'd,
Ranſom'd we were by thee.

lg.head: LXXI.
lg.l: We were thy lawful prize
And thou our lawful Lord;
Oh happy day then all did ſay
Who did believe thy word.

lg.head: LXXII.
lg.l: How deadly was that thrall
In which before we lay!
No Tyrants fell be ſo cruel
To uſe their ſlaves as they.

lg.head: LXXIII.
lg.l: Here was the coming in
Of all our future good:
Our hopes of all that ſince did fall
On this foundation ſtood.

lg.head: LXXIV.
lg.l: We never had come here,
Or this glory poſſeſt,
Unleſs thou Lamb had'ſt overcame
And given us this conqueſt.

lg.head: LXXV.
lg.l: Here through thou took'ſt the ſpoiles
Of all thine enemies;
And went'ſt on high triumphantly
With thoſe thy victories.

lg.head: LXXVI.
lg.l: Oh who this victory,
This Conqueſt gotten thus,
Can ſo ſet forth as ſuits it's worth?
Here's work enough for us.

lg.head: LXXVII.
lg.l: Thy mighty arme O Lord
Did to thy ſelf obtain
This viſhory, though we thereby
The benefit did gain.

lg.head: LXXVIII.
lg.l: Thy glorious Father who
Had choſen thee to this;
Who thee beheld, and in't upheld,
Then took thee up to bliſs.

lg.head: LXXIX.
lg.l: Oh how his ſoul was pleas'd
To ſee this field thus won:
Such conqueſt got, over that plot,
Which had us all undone!

lg.head: LXXX.
lg.l: Oh how he did delight
Thee to receive up then!
Placing thy Throne his right hand on
Above Angels and Men.

lg.head: LXXXI.
lg.l: And as he had thee choſe
This battel for to fight;
So did he chuſe thee ſtill to uſe
In all his acts of might.

lg.head: LXXXII.
lg.l: He made thee to be Lord
O're all things low and high,
That they ſhould be ſubject to thee
To all eternity.

lg.head: LXXXIII.
lg.l: And that thou might'ſt us bring
To all this happineſs,
Thee he appointed, and eke anointed
To glorious Offices.

lg.head: LXXXIV.
lg.l: A Prophet he thee made
To us to prophecy:
To ſhew the way which to thee lay
And guide us in't ſafely.

lg.head: LXXXV.
lg.l: And our High-Prieſt to be,
Having ſuch ſacrifice
Up-offered, ſo accepted
As God will ne'r't deſpiſe.

lg.head: LXXXVI.
lg.l: And that thou may'ſt always
Before his face appear,
For men to plead and intercede,
Their ſins away to bear.

lg.head: LXXXVII.
lg.l: And be the way whereby
We might an acceſs have
To th' holy place, to ſee God's face;
And fully us to ſave.

lg.head: LXXXVIII.
lg.l: And alſo to be King
Of Saints and Nations too:
Such to protect as be ſubject,
And all their foes ore-throw.

lg.head: LXXXIX.
lg.l: To all which Offices
As Man he thee ordain'd,
As a reward of that moſt hard
Service which thou ſuſtain'd.

lg.head: XC.
lg.l: And that unto all theſe
Thou might'ſt well furniſh'd be;
That his fulneſs thou ſhould'ſt poſſeſs,
He granted unto thee.

lg.head: XCI.
lg.l: Of which he did thee judge
Moſt worthy, ſo do we
Angels and Men, both now, and then
That thou ſhould'ſt higheſt be.

lg.head: XCII.
lg.l: Thou only worthy art
Oh Judah's Lyon ſtout!
To take that Book and on it look
That's ſeal'd within, without.

lg.head: XCIII.
lg.l: The Book of Prophecy
Or of God's counſels deep,
That none unſeal 't could, or reveal 't,
None now have cauſe to weep.

lg.head: XCIV.
lg.l: Thou Lamb was't found moſt meet
To open it and read:
It to unfold thou may'ſt be bold
Who for our ſins did'ſt bleed.

lg.head: XCV.
lg.l: And by thy blood us bought
From every Land, to be
God's Prieſts and Kings; and o're all things
On Earth now reign do we.

lg.head: XCVI.
lg.l: Yea all the Angels too
Fully agree to this;
That thou who was't ſlain for us, haſt
Moſt worthily all bliſs.

lg.head: XCVII.
lg.l: Power, wiſdom, riches, ſtrength,
Who may like thee poſſeſs?
Thou art worthy Kingly glory,
And as a Prieſt to bleſs.

lg.head: XCVIII.
lg.l: That what thou did'ſt obtain
Thou may'ſt diſtribute too;
Such honour bear as every where
Thy Fathers will to do.

lg.head: XCIX.
lg.l: For ſuch was this exployt
In which thou won'ſt this field,
That every thing to thee as King
All honour well may yield.

lg.head: C.
lg.l: And worthily thou haſt
In all thy power behav'd
Thy ſelf in all did ſince befall,
Wherein thou haſt us ſav'd.

lg.head: CI.
lg.l: For other battels yet
Remain'd for thee to fight
In which thou too thy love did'ſt ſhow
Thy wiſdom, ſtrength and might.

lg.head: CII.
lg.l: When thou had'ſt won that field,
And right to us had'ſt got;
Such yet our ſtate we did thee hate
Or to thee yielded not.

lg.head: CIII.
lg.l: Although the Serpent had
No right to us at all,
His arms were gone, law he had none,
To keep us ſtill in thrall.

lg.head: CIV.
lg.l: Yet by his ſubtlety
He ſtill did hold us faſt,
And to him we ſubject would be
And freedom would not taſte.

lg.head: CV.
lg.l: For what we had from him
Received formerly,
Did yet remain in every vein
Working effectually.

lg.head: CVI.
lg.l: We yet were ignorant,
Errour our minds poſſeſt:
Luſt in us lay and bare the ſway,
No good was in our breſt.

lg.head: CVII.
lg.l: For yet we knew no thee,
Who ſuch things for us wrought,
Yea falſly we conceiv'd of thee
In our vain mind and thought.

lg.head: CVIII.
lg.l: Oh what a do had'ſt thou
To gain us to thee here,
For through the lies of th' enemies
We much bewitched were.

lg.head: CIX.
lg.l: So much a • hored we
To their falſe flatteries,
Our eyes we clos'd, our ſelves oppos'd
Againſt thy verities.

lg.head: CX.
lg.l: Againſt us then to fight
We cauſed thee, that we
Our foes might leave, and thee receive
Our God and guide to be.

lg.head: CXI.
lg.l: Though not againſt us ſo
As what did us miſlead,
And us detain'd faſt bound and chain'd
Did'ſt thou therein proceed.

lg.head: CXII.
lg.l: It ſtill was thy deſign
Our ſinful ſouls to ſave;
But to deſtroy what did annoy
Our ſouls, and them inſlave.

lg.head: CXIII.
lg.l: A double edged ſword
Proceeded from thy mouth,
One edge kil'd ſin, and did us win
To love thee and thy truth.

lg.head: CXIV.
lg.l: The other edge cut down
Thoſe who held faſt their luſt,
Cleaving to it into the pit
Of wrath thou them haſt thruſt.

lg.head: CXV.
lg.l: And ſuch our folly was,
Our loathneſs ſin to leave,
That with th' unjuſt we might been thruſt
Our portion to receive.

lg.head: CXVI.
lg.l: But bleſſed be thy love
The ſpring of all our good,
And bleſt thy truth which from thy mouth
We heard and underſtood.

lg.head: CXVII.
lg.l: And bleſt thy patience,
And thy forbearance great,
Away to throw us thou waſt ſlow,
But thou did'ſt for us wait.

lg.head: CXVIII.
lg.l: Oh had'ſt thou been but quick
Our many faults to mark,
We had our lot with thoſe forgot
Who periſh in the dark.

lg.head: CXIX.
lg.l: And bleſt thy holy Spirit
Which • o thy truth diſplay'd
That by his hand it t' underſtand
At length he us all made.
Bleſt be thy wiſdome too
And thy great skilfulneſs,
In ordering all that did befall
In all occurrences.
Thou haſt the Learned's tongue
In skill thou art expert,
Both to imbrace and hide thy face
To kill and to convert.
Thy way is in the deep
Thy footſteps who hath known?
Hadſt thou nere frown'd and us nigh drown'd
We had been overthrown.
By Chaſtiſements, Reproofs,
Darkneſs and waters deep
Thou haſt us oft fought out and taught,
And us from Hell diſtd keep.
By them thou us haſt oft
So nurtur'd from our youth,
As us inclin'd and bow'd our mind
To liſten to thy truth.
Which through thy gentleneſs
And grace therein diſplay'd,
Though oft withſtood yet 'twas ſo good
As us 't obedient made.
Thou rod'ſt on proſperouſly
In meekneſs truth and love,
Which did us melt when we it felt
And our hearts to thee move.
Such were the ways whereby
Our hearts thou didſt ſubdue;
Error expelling and Sathan quelling
And making us anew.
Though divers methods thou
With us was pleas'd to take,
As thou didſt ſee might meeteſt be
Thy people us to make.
When thou didſt us eſpouſe
To thy ſelf by thy grace,
Us in thee planting, and to us granting
To have a fixed place.
Wherein thy love was rich
Surpaſſing every thought,
That we of thee branches ſhould be;
Who formerly were naught.
For we deſerv'd •• ave been
Cut down and wholly caſt,
Into the fire, to have the hire
Of all our evils paſt,
Herein thou didſt again,
A noble conqueſt make:
Us from our ſin we lived in,
Unto thy ſelf to take:
Oh noble Conqueror,
Thy power and might we ſee;
Oh Lord of Hoſts throughout all coaſts:
What one is like to thee.
Herein we do admire
The force of thy great love,
Our ſtubborn hearts, and bad deſerts,
Which got ſo much above.
And here began our bliſs,
Our happy ſtate, in which
Thou didſt us bring unto a ſpring,
And Fountain ſure and rich.
Here our new life began,
Becauſe we planted were;
Into a ſtock which did not mock,
But made us fruit to bear.
A Root moſt free of Sap
And living juice where from,
We did inherit both Life and Spirit,
Yea all good thence did come.
A Root which did us bear,
And give us living fruit;
Thy word declar'd it, thy Arm unbar'd it,
And made us with it ſute.
Thence all our Springs were found;
And all our fruits were good:
For all our own away were thrown,
Being unfit for food.
Oh what an happy ſtate,
Were we advanced to,
When into thee planted were we;
And made in thee to grow.
We one with thee became,
And of thy bliſs partook;
Better we had, and what did glad:
More than what we forſook.
God pittyed us before,
But now he did us own,
He in his love, did us approve:
And of him we were known.
The ſpecial love that was,
Thy lot thou didſt impart,
Gods loving face, that ſecret place
Which thou hadſt in Gods heart.
This was a happy Change,
While we in Adam were:
Our caſe was ſad, and very bad,
But now 'twas bleſſed here.
We had not God before,
Becauſe we had not thee;
In whom he is and gives his bliſs:
Then wretched men were we.
For though thou wert the hope,
And help of loſt mankind:
Yet without Thee, hope had not we:
Nor ſolid peace of mind.
But when in Thee thou gaveſt,
Sure title to all good:
Becauſe in Thee, the living Tree,
And Root of life we ſtood.
We were to Thee eſpous'd,
And Thou our Husband wert:
In thine Eſtate, for love and hate:
We thenceforth had our part.
Thy Father ours became;
Thine Angels were our guard:
Thy Riches ours, thy Wiſdom Power:
And thine was our reward.
Thine Enemies thence were ours,
And thy friends our friends too;
In Thee Elect God did reſpect,
And favour to us ſhow.
Yea hence is all the joy,
And glory we poſſeſs;
Hence Worlds abuſe, and Gods good uſe,
In joy and happineſs.
Thence God us took for Sons;
All former things were gone:
No wrath abode, his love He ſhow'd,
His face upon us ſhone.
But Thou hadſt other fights,
Wherein a ſhare had we;
At thy command, with Thee to ſtand,
Againſt the Enemie.
In which Thou wert our help,
Our Captain and our Guide:
Thy grace and love, they did us move,
Still with thee to abide.
The ſame that did at firſt,
Our hearts to thee ſubdue;
Was it prevail'd when Joes aſſaild,
And made us to Thee true.
In which thy grace ſupply'd
What in us wanting was;
Our weakneſſes, Miſcarriages;
There throught thou by didſt paſs.
Doubtleſs had'ſt thou not been
So cloth'd with Charity;
Our many halts, Retreats, and Faults:
Had made Thee caſt us by.
But none is like to Thee,
No Captain ſo will bear,
His Soldiers faults, retreats, and halts;
Or can their hearts ſo chear.
Thou waſt the prize for which
We fought, thy prize were we:
Our Enemies Plot was us t'have got
Quite out again from Thee.
Therefore they us inticed,
To leave the Faith wherein,
We one with Thee were made, and free
Were ſet from all our fin.
That was the bed of love:
The bond of Amity.
Therefore from that, to ſeparte
Us ſought the Enemy.
By many a Stratagem,
He did us oft aſſail,
By flatteries, and batteries,
Yet could he not prevail.
Although he had the world
As a great Magazine,
Of fiery Shafts fit for his Crafts
Our ſouls to undermine.
From whence on either ſide,
He did us oft aſſault,
With pleaſing ſights, or dreadful frights;
Yea we had many a fault.
From which he oft-times rais'd,
By his great policy
Such over caſts and dreadful blaſts,
As made us like to fly.
Oft-times us to allure
To take part againſt thee,
Pleaſures He brought into our thought,
Or glory made us ſee.
And ſundry other things,
Which with our fleſh did ſute,
From Trees to ſight fit for delight,
Moving to pluck the fruit.
Sometimes to puff us up,
That down he might us throw;
Our godlineſs, gifts, parts, graces,
Or works he would us ſhow.
Sometimes again by Cheats,
Which he thereto abus'd:
Some crooked way, He forth would lay,
Which was of Thee refus'd.
Sometimes this art he us'd,
The eaſly'r us to take,
As if of light, an Angel bright
He were, He ſhew would make.
Oft-times He alſo ſhew'd,
What dreadful things ſhould be,
From inſtruments of his intents,
If we would cleave to Thee.
The world he ſtir'd to wrath,
Againſt us for thy ſake;
So that of mocks, Scourges or Stocks,
Oft times we did partake.
Yea many hardſhips thence,
He preſſed us withal;
By many loſſes, and divers croſſes,
Moving from Thee to fall.
Not only our Eſtates,
He ſometimes from us caught;
But even our blood, like to a flood,
Was powred out full oft.
But Thou by thy good grace,
And help which thou didſt give,
Our Enemy, did make to fly,
And made our Souls to live.
Armour of righteouſneſs,
On each hand us did fend:
Thy glory bright, ſtood on our right;
O' th' eft wrath without end.
If to Thee and thy Word,
Thy right and perfect ways;
Firm we would cleave, and not thee leave,
Thou ſhew'dſt us endleſs praiſe.
But if Thee we would leave,
For worldly good, or fear of blood,
We endleſs torments ſee.
Which things eternal while,
Thou mad'ſt us keep in view,
Things temporal, we ſlighted all;
And not from Thee withdrew.
Thou wert our ſtrength and ſtay;
Our help was of thy grace:
Through thy defence, no fond pretence,
Did move us out of place.
Here alſo Thou didſt get.
The conqueſt o're our foes:
The victory, and the glory,
Unto thine honour goes.
We had been wholly foild,
And driven from Thee again;
But that our heads thou covered'ſt,
And didſt our hearts ſuſtain.
To thee we give the praiſe
Of our ſafety untill,
Through manifold perils untold,
Our days we did fulfill.
When yet one combate more,
Abode us generally:
To yield our Breath, paſſing through death,
And in the grave to ly.
Nor had we any might,
Againſt that Enemy:
Give way muſ we, to Gods decree;
That mankind once muſt dy.
Whereto by ſeveral ways,
We did arrive at length:
Diſeaſes ſome made thither come,
Or ſome decay of ſtrength.
By perſecutions ſome,
Through many deaths, much pain,
Who for thy name, ſlaughter and ſhame;
Did valiantly fuſtain.
For every one of which,
Praiſes to God and thee,
The lamb, by whom, all that did come,
Well ordered was we ſee.
Through thee it was for good,
That ſuch things we did bear:
Yea ſins alſo whence griefs did flow,
As they permitted were.
By our unrighteouſneſs,
And our offences ſore,
Thy righteouſneſs, was more expreſs,
And our ingagements more.
Thou turnſt them all to good,
Though from us they were ill:
And thou thy praiſe from thence didſt raiſe,
By thy great power and skill.
It was for good that Death
Thou didſt to us ordain:
Diſeaſes, pains, and ſuch remains;
As brought to duſt again.
For by the thoughts thereof,
And ſights, and feelings too;
Thou didſt us wake, more haſt to make,
To ſcape from endleſs woe.
They moved us the leſs,
The fleſh and world to mind:
And unto thee the more to flee,
And ſeek thy Grace to find.
They made us leſs to prize,
What did from thee allure:
Death did preſent, their injoyment
Falling and unſecure.
They made us leſs to dread,
What men us ſcared by;
While Temporal, we ſee them all,
And that no way but dy.
Yea while we alſo ſee,
That common Death no leſs;
Torments had oft, then what down brought,
Thoſe that did Thee confeſs.
Yea further, Death and grave,
This good unto us brought;
They gave us reſt, from what oppreſt,
When all our work was wrought.
We bleſs thee for them all,
For all together wrought;
For our great good, even death and blood,
And more joy to us brought.
While greater proofs we had,
Of thy great faithfulneſs:
How great each hour, thy love and power,
To help our weakneſſes.
For as our tryals did,
Thereby abound and grow;
So thy ſupports, and our comforts,
Did more upon us flow.
Oh happy was that time,
Happy the means by which;
Perſwaded we, became by Thee,
To take a courſe ſo rich.
Thy words to intertain,
And thy ſervants to be;
Suſtain the loſs, and bear the croſs,
And follow after Thee.
Oh bleſſed be that grace,
That power, and truth, and love;
Which did us draw, and keep in awe,
Notletting us remove.
For herein alſo Thou,
Our mighty Captain ſtood;
Our Enemy foild, his Armies ſpoild,
And filledſt us with good.
For though our fleſh fell down,
And Death it overcame:
And Fire or Grave, did it outbrave,
Yet we receiv'd no ſhame.
Yea more than Conquerors,
In all thoſe things we were:
Through thy great love, which did Thee move,
Our ſin and Death to beare.
This was our victory,
The faith we had in Thee:
That turn'd to meat, what did us eat,
And made us life to ſee.
But yet the full conqueſt,
Over that Enemie;
Thou didſt not make, till thou didſt take,
From Grave our dead Body.
Though when Death had us ſeis'd,
And Bodies dead did ly,
Our Spirit with Thee, thou took'ſt to be,
In thy joy and glory.
Where ſafety thou us gav'ſt,
And freedome from all ill.
In peace to reſt in thy ſweet breſt,
Our riſing time untill;
Yet Death and grave had ſo,
Our Bodies quite deprav'd:
As that it ſeem'd not to be deem'd,
That thence they could be ſav'd.
Such tranſmutations they,
Did ſo long time ſuſtain,
They were ſo jumb'd, diſperſt and crumbl'd
How could they riſe again?
But all this made but way,
For greater glory yet▪
And to compleat thy Conqueſt great;
Which thou could'ſt not but get.
For by thy powerful voice,
The Graves and place all,
Where we lay hid, preſently did,
Yield us up at thy call.
They had no power and might,
Againſt thy power and will;
Us to retain, and make remain:
Under corruption ſtill.
Thy Angels thou ſentſt ſorth,
And gatheredſt thine Elect:
That we by thee might honoured be,
With great love and reſpect.
And now we do injoy,
The Kingdom gloriouſly,
With Thee we raign and ſhall remain;
To all Eternity.
Oh what a Warriour ſtout,
Art thou, Thou meekeſt Lamb!
There's none could ſtand againſt thy hand;
But thou them overcame.
And Thou haſt given to us,
Thy Victories each one;
Our Enemies all, thou mad'ſt to fall;
And would'ſt not reign alone.
Thy Conqueſts now are full;
The field is fully clear:
There is no moe, left any foe;
Not one doth now appear.
For now thou haſt them all,
Deſtroyed totally,
They down are gone, where help is none;
In endleſs flames they fry.
And we, we reap the fruits,
Of all thy wars ſo great:
We have the end we did intend;
Thy pleaſant fruits we eat.
Now we are fully ſav'd,
From all our miſeries:
Broke is the Net, and we are ſet;
Above our Enemies.
All praiſe is due to thee,
Thou all things haſt well done:
Thou firſt and laſt, haſt all outcaſt,
Now ſorrows we have none.
A toilſome path we trod;
A tedious journey had:
A Wilderneſs of great diſtreſs,
But now thou'ſt made us glad.
In all our Pilgrimage,
And great temptations thou;
Didſt with us bide, haſt us ſupply'd,
And we be happy now.
Oh happy now our ſtate,
Our joys who can expreſs,
Well ſing we may, Hallelujah;
And thee for ever bleſs.

div.head: Another to the ſame Tune.

lg.l: A New triumphant Song,
Fil'd full of mirth and praiſe;
To Thee our King, now will we ſing;
Extolling thee always.
And well we may rejoyce,
O're all that wretched crue;
Who took delight, with great deſpight;
Our ruine to purſue.
Where are they all become,
That did us ſore oppreſs;
They all are gone, left there is none,
That may impair our bleſs.
Where is that old Serpent,
That dreadful Dragon fell?
Hallelujah, hee's not to day,
For Hee's thruſt down to Hell.
He and his Angels all,
That vexed us full ſore;
Lying in wait, for us with hate,
Deſtroy'd are evermore.
That dreadful burning Lake,
Of wrath ſo large and deep;
They'r thrown into, to bear their woe,
Where Sinners wail and weep.
Where are thoſe dreadful Beaſts,
That were his inſtruments;
With horns and heads, ſo full of dreads,
Breathing out puniſhments?
Where is their pompous train,
Their Names of blaſphemy?
There's not a Crown, unfallen down,
There's none of them on high.
Where now's the falſe Prophet,
Who all the World deceiv'd;
Who up did cry, and magnifie,
The Beaſt and him believ'd?
Who did him worſhip give,
And to his Image fall?
Name, Image, Mark, are all 'th' dark;
And their Adorers all.
Both Beaſ and Prophet falſe,
Are gone into the lake;
To bear their hire, in that great fire,
Whoſe burnings never ſlake.
Where is that painted Whore,
Which rode in Pomp and State?
Her gilded Cup, which was fil'd up,
With poyſonous liquors late?
Whom Earthly Kings ador'd,
As if ſhe ſure had been;
The only fit, in State to ſit,
As Soveraign Lady-Queen!
Who ſought and ſuckt out blood,
As if it had been ſweet;
Greateſt and leaſt, ſhe caus'd the Beaſt,
To trample under feet.
Becauſe we liked not
Th'intoxicating wine,
Which from her Cup, the World ſuckt up,
As if 'thad been divine.
Wher is ſhe now become,
Shee and her Lovers too,
Who did commit, what was not fit,
With her, and whoredomes doe?
Alas they are long ſince,
Burnt up and quite deſtroy'd:
Their Market's gone, and they did moan,
Who in her greatneſs joy'd.
Yea all the train of foes,
Who in our ſorrows laught,
Who Thee refus'd, and us abus'd,
Deſtruction hath them caught.
Thou haſt them overcome,
O Lamb, of Kings the King:
Well may we ſay, Hallelu-jah,
And praiſes to Thee ſing.
Where now is all that luſt,
That had in us a hold!
Its ſubtle Heads, Delights and dreads,
And branches manifold?
Which ſervice challenged,
And over us would reign:
Did us moleſt, and oft oppreſt,
And cau'd us ſmart and pain.
And where's the carnal mind,
That ſubtly did deviſe,
To draw us in, to commit ſin,
Through its deceits and lies.
And wheres the whoriſh heart,
Which oft withdrew from thee:
And did us cheat, with many a feat,
Making us ſorrow ſee?
Theſe foes are all deſtroy'd,
And we from them are free:
By thy ſharp ſword, thy powerful word,
They all conſumed be.
No errour in our mind,
Nor ignorance hath place:
Our hearts retain, nothing that's vain,
Thanks therefore to thy grace.
Nothing of unbelief,
Or of unlovingneſs:
No envy, hate, ſtrife or debate,
Pride, falſhood us poſſeſs.
Thou haſt us made ſo clean,
That in us there's no ſpot:
No wrinckled skin, no jot of ſin,
Nor weakneſs in our lot.
Thou our good husband art,
Who didſt our faults ſo bear;
And them reprove, with words of love,
As made us Thee to hear.
And what we heard of Thee,
Did waſh us wondrouſly:
But now thy ſight, makes us ſo white,
No blemiſh thou canſt ſpy.
Hallelujahs we ſing,
Sin us no more annoys:

l.hi: Hallelu-jah, Hallelu-jah,

lg.l: We no • have perfect joys.
Where is mortality?
All our Diſeaſes, pains;
Our Maſſineſs, which did us preſs?
Nought of them now remains.
Oh death where is thy ſting?
Grave where's thy victory?
Where be our fears, wrings, ſtrains and tears,
And all that made us cry?
Where are our oft complaints?
Our brui • es, breaches, wounds?
Our ſighs and moans? Our ſobs and groans?
Our famtings and our ſwounds?
Where are our ſleepleſs nights?
Where are our toilſome days;
Our gaſtly ſiglus Or • udain frights?
And what 〈◊〉 us amaze?
Where be our lameneſſes?
Deafneſs and Dumbneſs too?
Dimneſs of ſight, our want of light,
Crutches wherewith to go?
Where are our pangs and throws?
Our cruel ach's and ſmarts?
Our weary beds? Our dizzy heads?
Our ſad and doleful hearts?
Where are our Priſon bands?
Fetters? and Pillories?
The hurtful ſtocks? The taunts and mocks?
And furious outcries?
The Gallows and the racks?
The Gibbets? Beaſts? and Fire?
With whatſoe're, did rend and teare,
Or did us ver and tire?
Where is that rottenneſs,
That after Death took hold?
The ſtinking ſmell? The jaws of Hell?
And what elſe may be told.
Not one of theſe appears,
They are all fled and gone;
Hallelu-jah to Thee we ſay;
For 'tis from Thee alone.
All enemies thou ſubdu'dſt,
Oh who is like to Thee?
Thou Lord of Hoſts, art in all coaſts,
And thou haſt made us free.
Thou the ſtout Warriour art;
In Battel mighty ſtrong:
The man of War, by whom all are
Subdu'd; Thou art our Song.
By Thee we have eſcap't,
Whatever ill befell;
By Thy goodneſs we now poſſeſs,
Such joys as none can tell.
Thou from the midſt of foes,
Haſt brought us now to be;
With Angels bright, in Heav'nly light,
Companions with Thee.
NOw we may ſing and ſay,
What one is like unto;
Jeſuruns God, I'th' Heavens who rode,
To ſave us from all woe?
Th' Eternal God Thou wert,
Our refuge; and thine armes;
Under us were, us up to beare,
From all dangers and harms.
Thine everlaſting armes,
Whoſe ſtrength doth rever fail:
With them th' unjuſt, thou out haſt thruſt,
And made us to prevail.
Thou haſt deſtroy'd them all,
Who did us injury:
And now there's none, we dwell alone,
And are in great ſafety.
New Heavens and Earth have we,
A Land of Corn and Wine:
Thou'rt our fountain, and Thou doſt rain,
on us thy dew divine.
Oh happy Iſrael,
What one is like to us:
Sav'd by the Lord who is the ſword,
And ſhield moſt marvellous.
To which our foes are all,
At length as Lyers found:
Their planes high, where in ſafety,
They dwelt, we've trod to th'ground.
How glorious now our State,
Praiſes to Thee therefore:
Who can expreſs, the bleſſedneſs,
That we have evermore?
Our Body is become,
All glorious like to thine:
Thy glory bright, more than the light▪
Or Sun doth make us ſhine.
Like Angels now we be,
With whom we do converſe:
As nimble, and light, as pure and bright,
And through all things do pierce.
We need no Marriages,
More than they for increaſe:
Our Company can never dy,
Our joys ſhall never ceaſe.
Nay now we Angels judge,
Such is to us thy heart,
Thy very Throne, which Thou ſit'ſt on,
Thou doſt to us impart.
Our pleaſures now are full,
Immived, pure and clear:
We feel no cold, we wax not old,
Nothing our ſtrength doth wear.
No Winter time we have,
No withering or decay;
No Froſt nor Snow, No ſtorms do blo • ,
We have all Summers day,
Yet without parching heat,
Or ought that may annoy:
No ſcorching Sun o •• e us doth run,
Nought to allay our joy.
Great joy we alſo have,
In our ſociety:
Each one in other, as in our Brother,
Have great felicity.
Here Abel we injoy,
Who ſuffered firſt for Thee:
Enoch, Noah, and all thy way,
Who kept, our Partners be.
The holy Patriarks,
Before and ſince the flood;
Father renown'd, with glory crown'd,
And all their children good.
Thy holy Meſſengers,
Martyrs and Confeſſors:
Who faithful were, with us are here,
Of life inheritors.
But above all the reſt,
Thy preſence glorious;
Doth ſatisfie, eternally,
And make us triumph thus,
Like a City compact
And fully one are we:
Where without rent, or diſcontent,
We perfectly agree.
And perfectly we joy,
In one anothers good;
All perfectly, Thee glorifie,
Who for us ſhed'ſt thy blood.
In Thee for evermore,
We all have full content;
Thee to behold, Thee to unfold,
Is all our merriment.
No one doth ſeek himſelf;
Or in himſelf delights
But every one, is fixed on,
Thy glorious beauty bright.
Thou art our All; in whom,
Father and Spirit both;
And all good elſe, with us now dwells:
Thy glory doth us cloth.
In Thee we were compleat,
And had all good before:
Compleatly we, now injoy Thee,
And thine for evermore.
All excellencies which,
In the Creation were;
From Thee they flow'd, and Thee they ſhow'd,
In Thee we have them here.
Thou the beginning art,
Of Gods Creation good:
The ground moſt ſtrong and firm, whereon
All things were built and ſtood.
Thou art the perfect LIGHT,
Thou our of carkneſs ſhone;
And made us ſee, things as they be.
Light out of Thee there's none.
In earth, Thou art the Plant,
Of honour and renoun:
The righteous root, whence iſſu'd out,
What ever God doth own.
Thou Root of David art,
Whence all his hopes did ſpring;
Of that Kingdom, which now is come,
Whereof Thou art the King.
Thou art the fruitful Vine,
That doth that grape forth beare,
Which God and man, heartily can,
And have refreſht with chear.
Thy full obedience,
And pretious blood out ſhed;
Reliev'd our hearts, in all our ſmarts.
And God fully pleaſed.
Thou art the ſtately Palm,
And Olive freſh and green;
With weights oppreſt, thou grewſt up beſt,
Thou'rt always lively ſeen.
Thou art the green Firt-Tree,
Whence all our fruits abound,
And the Apple-Tree, where under we,
Have fragrant ſhadow found.
Thine Apples oftentimes,
Have us moſt chearful made:
Flagons of Wine, from Thee our Vine,
Oft times our hearts have ſtaid.
Like Cedar tall and ſtrong,
Which uſeth not to rot:
Such is thy raign, which doth remain,
Firm and decayeth not.
The ſtone of Iſrael,
And aged Rock thou art:
The precious ſtone, Foundation,
To ſtay and ſtrength the heart.
Thou art the Pearl of price,
For whom we all things ſold:
The Silver of ſtrength, whence days of length,
Thou'rt the moſt precious Gold.
Among the waters thou,
The Sea and Ocean art:
Whence all do flow, to which all owe,
The good they do impart.
All good from Thee proceeds,
And unto Thee again:
It is but meet, that all retreat,
Who doſt all good contain.
Thou art the Fountain too,
And Spring of waters pure,
Which run and live, Thou all doſt give,
Thy Streams are allways ſure.
All other things beſide,
Are Ciſterns, Pipes, and Pools▪
Who Thee forſook, and of them took,
Were all deluded fools.
Thou art the Life indeed,
All Life from Thee doth flow:
The Life and love, wherein we move,
We wholly to Thee owe.
For we were dead in ſins,
No living act could doe:
Till thy freſh ſent, did us prevent,
And reach our ſouls unto.
In Heaven the Morning Star,
Which in our darkſome night;
When helpeſs we, No hope could ſee.
Aroſe and Brought us light.
Thou art the glorious Sun,
Light, Heat, and life from Thee;
To all to whom, thy vertues come,
Sweetly imparted be.
The Sun of righteouſneſs,
Which hath upon us roſe:
And in thy wings, all healing brings,
And all our wounds haſt clos'd.
Oh what were we if Thee,
We did not now injoy?
Sure like to thoſe, who are thy foes,
And whom thou doſt deſtroy.
Its glorious to behold,
Thy glorious countenance;
It gives us ſight, fills with delight,
And doth our ſouls advance.
In thy light we do live,
And walk for evermore:
In Thee we play, and joy all day,
Hallelu-jah therefore.
Amongſt thoſe things on Earth,
Thou mad'ſt to live and move;
Like to the tame and harmleſs LAMB,
Thou wert in thy great love.
Gods Lamb moſt innocent,
Moſt meek and ſpotleſs, who
Clothing and food, affordeſt good,
And ill didſt undergo.
With greateſt patience,
Not anſwering again;
Though Thou defil'd waſt, and revil'd,
By men, and put to pain.
Gods Lamb indeed thou wert,
That ſacrifice whereby;
Our peace was made, wrath aſide laid,
And we receiv'd mercy.
Thy fleſh thou gav'ſt for food,
Thy blood was drink indeed:
Feeding on that, we comfort gat,
And ſtrength in every need.
Thy righteouſneſs us cloth'd,
And thy vertues ſo high;
And moſt divine, do make us ſhine,
Always moſt gloriouſly.
Thou art the Lyon too,
For ſtrength and power: ſo thoſe
Thee oft have found, unto their wound,
Who were thy mortal foes.
In thy great ſtrength Thou haſt
Upon them roard, whereby
They were thy prey, and behold they,
Torn and devour'd now ly.
Oh it was well for us,
That Thou our General:
A Lyon wer' • , elſe we like Harts,
Had ſoon been r • uted all.
Thou art the UNICORN,
Thy Horn is ſtately high:
Thy power and might, alone to flight,
Hath put the Enemy.
Thou art the Glory, and
The ſum of all the reſt.
The Man thou art, who haſt the heart,
With underſtanding beſt.
For Thee were all things made,
And they were given to Thee:
In Heaven and Earth, above beneath,
And in the Ocean Sea.
Thou art the Male to us,
And we thy Femal be:
Thou the Husband, us to command,
And we the ſpouſe to Thee.
For Thee we framed were,
And of Thee ſecretly:
While thou didſt ſleep, a ſleep ſo deep,
As for our fins to dy.
Out of thy fleſh we are,
And out of thy bone too:
One Soul we have, which thy Breath gave,
Thy Heavenly things to know.
In us thou tak'ſt delight,
And our delight thou art;
Thou with thy grace, doſt us embrace,
And lay'ſt us in thy heart.
While thou didſt us embrace,
And we ſubmit to Thee;
There did proceed, from Thee that Seed,
Which made us fruitful be.
Which in thine own Image,
Thou didſt beget, we bear;
Thy Company, makes us happy,
All our eternal year.
Thou art the Angel too,
The Meſſenger by whom;
The Heavenly grant, Gods Covenant,
Down unto us did come.
Yea all the things of weight,
We in the Scriptures read;
Compleatly be, fulfil'd in Thee,
As might be mentioned.
The Sabboath or the Reſt,
Thou art, and Thou doſt give:
Thou art our reſt, God hath Thee bleſt,
Joyful in Thee we live.
From all his mighty works,
God ay in Thee doth ceaſe:
Thou art the end, whereto they tend,
Thou art our Reſt and peace.
In Thee by us injoy'd,
Our works are ended all:
No travail more, or labour ſore,
Or grief ſhall us befall.
We alſo are thy Reſt,
For now that us thou haſt:
Thy works are o're, for evermore,
Thy labours all are paſt.
Thou the ſweet Garden art,
The Garden of delight;
The Paradiſe, where pleaſure lies,
And what doth pleaſe our ſight.
And we thy Garden are,
In us thou pleaſure tak'ſt:
Us to poſſeſs, Taſt of and dreſs,
Thou oft thy buſineſs mad'ſt.
Thou art the TREE of LIFE,
Which pleaſant fruits doth bear:
Whereof we leave, have to receive,
And Death we cannot fear.
The River too thou art,
Of living waters pure:
Thy ſtreams go out, and run about,
With joys both full and ſure.
Thou haſt been unto us,
The ARK; wherein we were
Shut up and kept, not to be ſwept,
Away, with floods of fear.
Thou art the Covenant too,
Made between us and God:
In Thee we be, for ever f • ee,
From fears of future flood.
Yea Thou that Covenant art,
In which we are the Lords:
And God our Tower, by his great power,
All bleſs to us affords.
In and with Thee He hath giv'n
The everlaſting Land:
Whereof we be, The heirs with Thee,
In whom our lots do ſtand.
In Thee from all our fleſh,
We circumciſed were:
The Bleſſed ſeed, thou art indeed,
Whence we be bleſſed here.
Thou art the high Father,
And we thy Children be:
We are the Kings, and the off-ſpring,
Proceeded out of Thee.
Thou art the Iſaac,
The heir of promiſe, who
Our laughter art, Thou mak'ſt our heart
Rejoyce after our woe.
Thou art the Iſrael,
The Prince with God and Man:
By both aſſail'd, thou haſt prevaild,
With both the field thou wan.
Thou the true Joſeph art,
Firſt by thy Brethren ſold:
To ſufferings by, their great envy,
Expoſed manifold.
But from thoſe great ſuffrings,
Thou wert exalted high;
To have the ſtore: to Thee therefore,
All had reſort to buy.
Thou the meek Moſes art,
Drawn out of waters great:
Whom alſo thy, People thruſt by,
And badly did intreat.
Thou unto us waſt ſent,
A Prophet, Prieſt and King;
From dreadful thrall, us out to call,
And hither us to bring.
Thou ſhewd'ſt thy mighty ſigns,
On Pharaoh and his Land;
The Dragon fell, to us cruel,
And who with him did ſtand.
Thou brought'ſt us forth from thall,
And lead'ſt us through the Sea:
Of troubles great, which though they beat,
Thou mad'ſt a wall to be.
A means of ſafety from,
The Dragon who purſu'd;
Thou didſt us ſave, where they their grave,
Did make, by thee ſubdu'd.
Thou ledſt us through the wide,
And howling wilderneſs:
Thou us ſtoodſt by, led'ſt us ſafely,
Through fears and great diſtreſs.
Yea there thou all things wert,
To us that they injoy'd;
The Paſchal Lamb, Through thee we came,
From the world undeſtroy'd.
Even through thee crucify'd,
Beſprinkled with thy Blood;
Through faith we eat, thy fleſh as meat,
And in all ſlaughters ſtood.
Thou our Lawgiver wert,
A Law of Life and grace:
Thou gav'ſt from on, the Mount-Sion,
Thy high and holy place.
Which in our fleſhly hearts,
Thou too imprintedſt ſo;
That we clave faſt, unto the laſt,
And would not from thee go.
Thou that great Prophet art,
By whom the Father did:
Thoſe things reveal, which under Seal,
Lay in his boſome hid.
Thou waſt our Ark of ſtrength,
Gods preſence in thee was:
By Thee we were, ſafe in each fear,
And ſafely on did paſs.
Thou waſt that Tabernacle,
Where God with us did dwell:
He would in Thee worſhipped be,
And there his mind did tell.
Thou waſt the Sacrifice,
Our ſins to take away;
Us to atone, and make at one,
With thy Father for ay.
Yea Altar and Incence,
And Mercy-Seat thou wert;
Laver and Prieſt, Shoulder and Breaſt,
Thy holy Prieſthoods part.
The Light and Candleſtick,
The Table and Shew-bread;
Thou to us wert, though Thou impart,
Thy glory as our head.
Thou wert our Manna while,
In Wilderneſs we were;
Dayly did we, pertake of Thee,
Till we arrived here.
And oft we guilty were,
Of ſlighting Thee through luſt;
Which made us crave, ſuch things to have,
As were for us unjuſt.
Through which ſometimes we did
Gods wrath upon us bring;
So as to ſend, the fiery Feind,
Our Souls to vex and ſting.
Againſt the which Thou wert,
Our Brazen Serpent ſure:
While we betook, ou • ſelves to look,
To Thee thou didſt us cure.
Thou art the Rock from which,
By Moſes Rod, when ſmore;
By curſe of Law, Thy blood to draw,
Freſh waters iſſu'd out.
Even Heavenly Doctrine,
And Heavenly comforts ſweet,
Where with in all, that did befall,
We every where did meet.
Nay all the Types were ſhort,
Of thy perfections great;
Thou didſt exceed, and doſt indeed,
All things that thee forth ſet.
Moſes did fail and dy,
Before the peoples reſt:
But thou doſt live, and to us give,
The land thats ever bleſt.
For Thou our Joſhuah art,
Who Finiſhedſt our way:
Thou dry'dſt the River, Even Death for ever,
And here thou mak'ſt us ſtay.
Thou our Great Captain art,
By thee and thy command,
Our battels fought, and we are brought,
Into this pleaſant Land.
This glorious Land of Reſt,
Where we all fulneſs have:
What ever thou, didſt promiſe, now,
W'injoy, and more can't crave.
Thou'rt our Deliverer,
The Judge who didſt us ſave:
By thy juſt Doom, we here are come,
This glorious Reſt to have.
Where all in and with thee,
We have this endleſs day:
Therefore O King, to Thee we ſing,
Hallelu-jah alway.
Thou the true David art,
Over all Iſrael ſet:
His Royal Throne, Thou firſt upon,
Thy Kingdom's very great.
To which Thou art advanc'd,
From Sheol's dreadful hand:
From ſuffering by, the great envy,
Of thoſe that rul'd the Land.
Thou art th' Anointed King,
That haſt beat down our foe:
A City great and built compleat,
Thou haſt us brought unto.
Where thou the beauty art,
The Sun and glorious Light:
For here we thee, enjoy and ſee,
Thy Majeſty moſt bright.
In Thee we God injoy,
And his Sons fully are:
With us he dwells, our joy excels,
Our City is moſt rare.
Its Gates are precious Pearls,
Its Streets are fineſt Gold.
All things are pure, precious and ſure,
And glorious to behold.
For Gods own glory here,
For evermore doth ſhine:
And us to fill, with pleaſure ſtill,
All things do here combine.
O happy glorious ſtate,
Who can it all declare?
Beyond all wiſhes, beyond all bleſſes,
Our happineſſes are.
Thou art our Solomon,
In peace and glory, raign'ſt:
B • none diſturb'd, for thou haſt curb'd,
All that roſe thee againſt.
And in this Kingdome we,
As Kings with thee do ſit;
In Stately ſeat, and glory great,
As thou haſt thought it fit.
That glorious Pomp and State,
Of Solomon of old:
Though it was found, greatly beyond,
All that of him was told,
Yet was but a ſhort type,
Of this thy glory high;
In which thou raignſt, beſet with Saints,
In glorious Majeſty.
In which ten thouſand fold,
Ten thouſand times nombred;
Thou doſt regard, us to reward,
For all we ſuffered.
Our ſufferings were but light,
And momentany; but
They'r weighty Crowns, endleſs renouns,
Which Thou haſt on us put.
Thy Wiſdome too exceeds,
Wiſe Solomon's by far:
Thou all things know'ſt, and clearly ſhew'ſt,
None may with Thee compare.
That ſtately Temple which,
By Solomon was made,
Thou doſt excel, in whom doth dwell:
All fullneſs o'th' Godhead.
All his perfections here,
Are gloriouſly diſplayd;
And we them ſee, beyond what we,
Ever heard of them ſaid.
Yea Thou to us impart'ſt,
This glory too: for we,
An holy place, for Gods good Grace,
Are builded up by Thee.
Thou the foundation art,
And precious Corner Stone:
Thou doſt us bear, and cauſe t' adhere,
To God and every one.
Through Thee God alſo dwells
With his perfections pure;
In us always, to his great praiſe,
For ever to endure.
And that's the top and height,
Of all our happineſs;
That God with us, we enjoy thus,
The Fountain of all bleſs.
All which we have in Thee,
And with Thee perfectly;
Who can Thee reach, or who can preach,
All thy perfections high?
Oh thanks for evermore,
To God and to the Lamb:
Through Gods grace good, and the Lambs blood,
It is that here we came.
Where ſulneſs of al • joy,
And pleaſures evermore;
Our portion be, therefore we Thee,
For ever do adore.
The Scriptures we need not,
In dark they were our light:
Thou art our book, on Thee we look,
And all things ſee aright.
Tou art our GENESIS,
In Thee we were create:
Thou'rt our Beginning, without Beginning,
And End beyond all date.
By thee we out of duſt,
Or nought our beings had:
All things in Thee, to us are free,
And we have nothing bad.
Thou art our EXODUS,
Our goings out of thrall.
Thou didſt us ſave, deliverance gave,
By thy high heav'nly call.
Thour't our LEVITICUS,
Through Thee to God we clave:
Through thy Prieſthood, and offrings good,
He never did us leave.
We alſo to be Prieſts,
Were all by thee anneald:
Our Leproſie, is cleans'd by Thee,
And all our iſſues heal'd.
Thou art our NUMBERER,
In thee inrold we be:
Where God doth own, in thee is ſhown,
Our Genealogie.
Thou art our Second LAW,
A perfect ſummary:
Of Gods mercies, and our duties,
We do in thee deſcry.
Thou art our JOSHUAH,
Our Saviour, Judge, and King:
What we omitted, or elſe forgetted,
Thou to our mind doſt bring.
Its thou in EPHRATA,
That haſt done worthily:
Poor Gen iles thou, when they did bow,
Haſt lifted up on high.
Thou art the perfect Scribe,
The writer of Gods Law:
Freedome declar'd, and all repaird,
By thee, we alſo ſaw.
The poor and patient JOB,
Made poor and rich again,
Who thee oppreſt, at thy requeſt,
Yet mercy did obtain.
Thou the ſweet Singer art,
The chief Muſitian, who:
The Inſtrument, didſt firſt invent,
And play'ſt upon it too.
Thou art our PSALM and Song,
Our hearts and tongues always:
Thou through thy love, doſt tune, frame, move,
To fing forth all thy praiſe.
Thou only fulneſs haſt,
All without thee is vain:
Thou art the Preacher, and heavenly Teacher,
Who doſt in Salem Raign.
Thou'rt the Beloved one,
The ſwift Roe, or young Hart:
The Song of Songs, to Thee belongs,
Who its chief Subject art.
Thy Teſtimony is,
Of all the Prophets old;
The quinteſſence, and thou the ſenſe,
Of Proverbs doſt unfold.
Thou from a low degree,
Haſt raiſ'd us to the Throne;
The Righteous ſeed, Thou haſt all freed,
Here's Lamentations none.
Thou art the Goſpels ſum,
The tidings of great joy;
Bleſſings have we, and peace in Thee,
Nothing doth us annoy.
Thou Gods Epiſtle wert,
His mind in Thee He writ;
When we abſent were, he thee ſent,
And Thou diſcoveredſt it.
Thou art the end of all,
In Thee God doth unfold;
And hath reveal'd, what lay conceal'd,
In Thee we All behold.
Thou all art, and in all:
ALPHA and OMEGA:
Wherefore to Thee, ever do we,
Sing, Oh Hallelu-ſah.

div.head: To the Holy Spirit.

lg.l: ANd yet again wee'll ſing: and ſtrike our ſtrings,
Wee'l ſhew forth whence the ſpring
Of joy that makes us ſing,
